6. Eigenvectors and Diagonalization

6.1 Matrix of a Linear Mapping, Similar Matrices

A linear mapping L:Rn→RnL:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n}L:Rn→Rn is sometimes called a linear operator. This is often done when we wish to stress the fact that the domain and codomain of the linear mapping are the same. Let B={v⃗1,...,v⃗n}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{n}\}B={v1​,...,vn​} be a basis for Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn and let L:Rn→RnL:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n}L:Rn→Rn be a linear operator. The B\mathcal{B}B-matrix of L is defined to be [L]B=[[L(v⃗1)]B⋅⋅⋅[L(v⃗n)]B][L]_{\mathcal{B}}=[[L(\vec{v}{1})]_{\mathcal{B}} \cdot\cdot\cdot [L(\vec{v}_{n})]_{\mathcal{B}}][L]B​=[[L(v1)]B​⋅⋅⋅[L(vn​)]B​] It satisfies [L(x⃗)]B=[L]B[x⃗]B[L(\vec{x})]_{\mathcal{B}}=[L]_{\mathcal{B}}[\vec{x}]_{\mathcal{B}}[L(x)]B​=[L]B​[x]B​.

e.g. Let L be a linear mapping with standard matrix [L]=[3−1−13][L]=\begin{bmatrix}3&-1\\ -1&3\end{bmatrix}[L]=[3−1​−13​] and B={[11],[1−1]}\mathcal{B}=\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 1\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}1\\ -1\end{matrix}]\}B={[11​],[1−1​]}. To find [22]B[\begin{smallmatrix}2\\2\end{smallmatrix}]_{\mathcal{B}}[22​]B​, we solve c1[11]+c2[1−1]=[22]c_1\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix}1\\-1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}2\\2\end{bmatrix}c1​[11​]+c2​[1−1​]=[22​]. c1+c2=2c_1+c_2=2c1​+c2​=2 c1−c2=2c_1-c_2=2c1​−c2​=2 Adding equations: 2c1=4⇒c1=22c_1=4 \Rightarrow c_1=22c1​=4⇒c1​=2. L([1−1])=[3−1−13][1−1]=[4−4]L(\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}) = \begin{bmatrix}3&-1\\ -1&3\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}4\\ -4\end{bmatrix}L([1−1​])=[3−1​−13​][1−1​]=[4−4​]. Theorem 6.1.7

If A and B are n×nn\times nn×n matrices such that P−1AP=BP^{-1}AP=BP−1AP=B for some invertible matrix P, then

  1. rank A=A=A= rank B.
  2. det A=A=A= det B.
  3. tr A=tr BA=\text{tr }BA=tr B where tr A is defined by tr A=∑i=1naii\text{tr }A=\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{ii}tr A=∑i=1n​aii​ and is called the trace of a matrix.

If A and B be n×nn\times nn×n matrices such that P−1AP=BP^{-1}AP=BP−1AP=B for some invertible matrix P, then A is said to be similar to B. If A is similar to B, prove that AnA^{n}An is similar to BnB^{n}Bn.

6.2 Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

Let A be an n×nn\times nn×n matrix. If there exists a vector v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0 such that Av⃗=λv⃗A\vec{v}=\lambda\vec{v}Av=λv, then the scalar λ\lambdaλ is called an eigenvalue of A and v⃗\vec{v}v called an eigenvector of A corresponding to λ\lambdaλ. The pair (λ,v⃗)(\lambda,\vec{v})(λ,v) is called an eigenpair.

Let L:Rn→RnL:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n}L:Rn→Rn be a linear operator. If there exists a vector v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0 such that L(v⃗)=λv⃗L(\vec{v})=\lambda\vec{v}L(v)=λv then λ\lambdaλ is called an eigenvalue of L and v⃗\vec{v}v is called an eigenvector of L corresponding to λ\lambdaλ. Why do you think we have the v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0 condition? (If v⃗=0⃗\vec{v}=\vec{0}v=0, then A0⃗=λ0⃗A\vec{0}=\lambda\vec{0}A0=λ0 becomes 0⃗=0⃗\vec{0}=\vec{0}0=0 for any λ\lambdaλ, which is trivial and doesn't define unique eigenvalues.)

e.g. Consider again the linear mapping L:R2→R2L:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{2}L:R2→R2 with standard matrix [L]=[3−1−13][L]=\begin{bmatrix}3&-1\\ -1&3\end{bmatrix}[L]=[3−1​−13​]. As we saw: L(1,1)=[L][11]=[3−1−13][11]=[22]=2[11]L(1,1)=[L]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}3&-1\\ -1&3\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 2\end{bmatrix}=2\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}L(1,1)=[L][11​]=[3−1​−13​][11​]=[22​]=2[11​] L(1,−1)=[L][1−1]=[3−1−13][1−1]=[4−4]=4[1−1]L(1,-1)=[L]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}3&-1\\ -1&3\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}4\\ -4\end{bmatrix}=4\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}L(1,−1)=[L][1−1​]=[3−1​−13​][1−1​]=[4−4​]=4[1−1​] Thus, (2,[11])(2,\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix})(2,[11​]) and (4,[1−1])(4,\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix})(4,[1−1​]) are eigenpairs of [L]. Also, 2 is an eigenvalue of L with eigenvector [11]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}[11​], while 4 is another eigenvalue with corresponding eigenvector [1−1]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}[1−1​].

This is not λv⃗1\lambda\vec{v}_1λv1​. No (b) v⃗2=[−131]\vec{v}_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}-1\\ 3\\ 1\end{bmatrix}v2​=​−131​​. Yes (c) v⃗3=[10−1]\vec{v}_{3}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\\ -1\end{bmatrix}v3​=​10−1​​. No. A(2v⃗)=2(Av⃗)=2(λv⃗)=(2λ)v⃗A(2\vec{v}) = 2(A\vec{v}) = 2(\lambda\vec{v}) = (2\lambda)\vec{v}A(2v)=2(Av)=2(λv)=(2λ)v. This means 2λv⃗=4λv⃗2\lambda\vec{v} = 4\lambda\vec{v}2λv=4λv, which implies 2λv⃗=0⃗2\lambda\vec{v}=\vec{0}2λv=0. Since v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0, then 2λ=0⇒λ=02\lambda=0 \Rightarrow \lambda=02λ=0⇒λ=0. So only if λ=0\lambda=0λ=0. No, only true when λ=0\lambda=0λ=0 or v⃗=0\vec{v}=0v=0. e.g. Can you imagine a scenario where (λ,v⃗1)(\lambda,\vec{v}_{1})(λ,v1​) and (λ,v⃗2)(\lambda,\vec{v}_{2})(λ,v2​) are eigenpairs of A, with v⃗1≠v⃗2\vec{v}_{1}\ne\vec{v}_{2}v1​=v2​? Yes. For example, A=[3003]A=\begin{bmatrix}3&0\\ 0&3\end{bmatrix}A=[30​03​], λ=3\lambda=3λ=3. v⃗1=[10]\vec{v}_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}v1​=[10​] and v⃗2=[01]\vec{v}_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}v2​=[01​].

From the definition, an eigenpair of A, (λ,v⃗)(\lambda,\vec{v})(λ,v), requires v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0 with Av⃗=λv⃗A\vec{v}=\lambda\vec{v}Av=λv. Av⃗−λv⃗=0⃗A\vec{v}-\lambda\vec{v}=\vec{0}Av−λv=0 Av⃗−λIv⃗=0⃗A\vec{v}-\lambda I\vec{v}=\vec{0}Av−λIv=0 (A−λI)v⃗=0⃗(A-\lambda I)\vec{v}=\vec{0}(A−λI)v=0 where v⃗\vec{v}v is a solution to the homogeneous system [A−λI∣0⃗][A-\lambda I|\vec{0}][A−λI∣0]. Since we need v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0 the eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ exists if and only if this system has infinitely many solutions (i.e., non-trivial solutions). In turn, this means A−λIA-\lambda IA−λI is not invertible, or, det(A−λI)=0.det(A-\lambda I)=0.det(A−λI)=0. Once such a λ\lambdaλ has been found, we can determine its associated eigenvectors by solving the homogeneous system (A−λI)v⃗=0⃗(A-\lambda I)\vec{v}=\vec{0}(A−λI)v=0.

Let A be an n×nn\times nn×n matrix. The characteristic polynomial of A is the n-th degree polynomial CA(λ)=det(A−λI)C_{A}(\lambda)=det(A-\lambda I)CA​(λ)=det(A−λI). If there is no risk of confusion, we will sometimes write C(λ)C(\lambda)C(λ) instead of CA(λ)C_{A}(\lambda)CA​(λ).

Theorem 6.2.8

A scalar λ\lambdaλ is an eigenvalue of an n×nn\times nn×n matrix A if and only if CA(λ)=0C_{A}(\lambda)=0CA​(λ)=0.

Let A be an n×nn\times nn×n matrix with eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ. We call the nullspace of A−λIA-\lambda IA−λI the eigenspace of A corresponding to λ\lambdaλ. The eigenspace is denoted EλE_{\lambda}Eλ​.

e.g. Find all eigenvalues and a basis for each eigenspace for A=[12101200−2]A=\begin{bmatrix}1&2&1\\ 0&1&2\\ 0&0&-2\end{bmatrix}A=​100​210​12−2​​. CA(λ)=det(A−λI)=∣1−λ2101−λ200−2−λ∣C_{A}(\lambda)=det(A-\lambda I)=\begin{vmatrix}1-\lambda&2&1\\ 0&1-\lambda&2\\ 0&0&-2-\lambda\end{vmatrix}CA​(λ)=det(A−λI)=​1−λ00​21−λ0​12−2−λ​​. 6.3 Diagonalization

An n×nn\times nn×n matrix A∈Mn×n(R)A\in M_{n\times n}(\mathbb{R})A∈Mn×n​(R) is said to be diagonalizable if A is similar to a diagonal matrix D∈Mn×n(R)D\in M_{n\times n}(\mathbb{R})D∈Mn×n​(R). If P−1AP=DP^{-1}AP=DP−1AP=D, then we say that P diagonalizes A.

Remark: For now, we will restrict ourselves to diagonalizing real matrices with real eigenvalues. That is, if A has a non-real eigenvalue, then we will say that A is not diagonalizable over R\mathbb{R}R. In Section 6.5, we will look at diagonalizing matrices over the complex numbers.

Diagonalizability Test

If A is an n×nn\times nn×n matrix whose characteristic polynomial factors as CA(λ)=(λ−λ1)aλ1⋅⋅⋅(λ−λk)aλkC_{A}(\lambda)=(\lambda-\lambda_{1})^{a_{\lambda_{1}}}\cdot\cdot\cdot(\lambda-\lambda_{k})^{a_{\lambda_{k}}}CA​(λ)=(λ−λ1​)aλ1​​⋅⋅⋅(λ−λk​)aλk​​ where λ1,...,λk\lambda_{1},...,\lambda_{k}λ1​,...,λk​ are the distinct eigenvalues of A, then A is diagonalizable if and only if gλi=aλig_{\lambda_{i}}=a_{\lambda_{i}}gλi​​=aλi​​ for 1≤i≤k1\le i\le k1≤i≤k.

Corollary 6.3.6

If A is an n×nn\times nn×n matrix with n distinct eigenvalues, then A is diagonalizable.

  1. Find and factor the characteristic polynomial C(λ)=det(A−λI)C(\lambda)=det(A-\lambda I)C(λ)=det(A−λI).
  2. Let λ1,...,λn\lambda_{1},...,\lambda_{n}λ1​,...,λn​ denote the n roots of C(λ)C(\lambda)C(λ) (repeated according to multiplicity).
  3. If any of the eigenvalues λi\lambda_{i}λi​ are not real, then A is not diagonalizable over R\mathbb{R}R.
  4. Find a basis for the eigenspace of each distinct eigenvalue λj\lambda_{j}λj​ by finding a basis for the nullspace of A−λjIA-\lambda_{j}IA−λj​I.
  5. If gλj<aλjg_{\lambda_{j}}<a_{\lambda_{j}}gλj​​<aλj​​ for any λj\lambda_{j}λj​, then A is not diagonalizable.
  6. Otherwise, form a basis {v⃗1,...,v⃗n}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{n}\}{v1​,...,vn​} for Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn of eigenvectors of A by using Theorem 6.3.4. Let P=[v⃗1⋅⋅⋅v⃗n]P=[\begin{matrix}\vec{v}_{1}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&\vec{v}_{n}\end{matrix}]P=[v1​​⋅⋅⋅​vn​​].
